question:
(a)

How many strings are there over the set {a, b, c} that have length 10 in which no two consecutive characters are the same? For example, the string "abcbcbabcb" would count and the strings "abbbcbabcb" and "aacbcbabcb" would not count.
answer: There are three choices for the first character. There are two choices in selecting each of the next 9 characters from left to right because each character can be any element from the set {a, b, c}, except the one that was chosen to be the previous character. Putting together all the choices by the generalized product rule, the number of strings of length 10 that do not have two consecutive characters that are the same is 3·2 9 .
